newsitem.title: GERMANY: Taiwan pig epidemic to cut feed demand - Oil World.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan pig epidemic to cut feed demand - Oil World.

text.p: The outbreak of foot and mouth disease in Taiwan's pigmeat industry is likely to reduce local feed demand throughout 1997, the independent Oil World newsletter said.
The disease, which has affected more than 1,000 hog farms since March 19, forced Taiwan to suspend pork exports and cut production.
Taiwan's April-September 1997 soybean crushings were forecast at 1.24 million tonnes, down from 1.38 million in the same 1996 period, Oil World said.
Taiwan would produce less soyoil and lard in that period, which should bring higher imports of palm oil, soyoil, sun oil and tallow.
Total vegetable oil and animal fats import demand was forecast at 287,000 tonnes in Oct/Sept 1996/97, up by 40,000 tonnes from 95/96.

Oil World also said the loss of Taiwan pork exports on the world markets should mean higher pork prices in Europe and North America, where Taiwan's traditional customers such as Japan would turn instead.
Feed requirements in the United States and Canada and Denmark were likely to rise in line with higher export demand.
